title: 107_hr5596
content:
Exemption for certain state and local political committees from notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendment allows political committees of state or local candidates, as well as state or local committees of political parties, to be exempt from notifying the Secretary and reporting requirements. Effective date aligns with previous amendments. Amendment exempts qualified State or local political organizations from certain notification and reporting requirements under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Qualified organizations are defined as those solely focused on influencing the selection of individuals for State or local public office. The curr_chunk states that the organization's purpose is to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of individuals to State or local public office, subject to State law reporting requirements. The curr_chunk requires information on expenditures, contributions, and the individuals involved in the transactions for the organization influencing the selection of individuals for public office. The curr_chunk outlines requirements for reporting expenditures and contributions by organizations, including making reports public and available for inspection. Certain differences in state laws are disregarded, such as varying minimum amounts for reporting and not requiring identification of contributors' employers. The curr_chunk outlines reporting requirements for organizations, including disclosing contributors' employers, occupations, expenditure purposes, and dates of contributions and expenditures. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which an organization can still be considered a qualified State or local political organization despite making minor errors in compliance with reporting and inspection requirements. It also specifies that a federal candidate or office holder cannot be considered part of such an organization if they control or significantly participate in its activities or solicit contributions, unless the contributions are minimal and made without their knowledge or consent. The amendments made by this section regarding soliciting contributions and directing disbursements by an organization shall take effect as if included in Public Law 106-230. SEC. 3. EXEMPTION FROM ANNUAL RETURN REQUIREMENTS. Income Tax Returns Required Only for Political Organization Taxable Income. Income Tax Returns Not Subject to Disclosure. Disclosure by the secretary and public inspection amended. Information Returns amended for political organizations. Information Returns amended for political organizations. Section 6033 of the Tax Code is updated to require political organizations with gross receipts of $25,000 or more to file annual returns. Qualified State or local political organizations must meet a higher threshold of $100,000. The returns must include necessary information for section 527 compliance. The Secretary can make modifications to only require necessary information for section 527 compliance and include other necessary details. Certain organizations are exempt from filing, such as State or local political committees, candidate committees, national party committees, and certain campaign committees. The amendments made by this section will take effect as if included in the amendments made by Public Law 106-230. The Secretary has the discretion to exempt certain organizations from filing information returns if it is deemed unnecessary for efficient tax administration. SEC. 4. NOTIFICATION OF INTERACTION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Federal Election Commission, shall publicize the effect of the amendments made by this Act and the interaction of requirements to file a notification or report under section 527 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and reports under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Information provided shall be included in any form, instruction, notice, or guidance issued to the public regarding reporting requirements of political organizations or under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF FILING AMOUNTS. The Secretary may waive tax or amounts imposed on organizations for failure to comply with requirements if due to reasonable cause. Effective after June 30, 2000.

SEC. 6. MODIFICATIONS TO SECTION 527 ORGANIZATION DISCLOSURE PROVISIONS. (a) Unsegregated Funds Not To Avoid Tax.--Amends section 527(i) of the Internal Revenue Code to include exempt function income regardless of segregation. 
(b) Procedures for Assessment and Collection of Amounts.--Amends section 527(j) to specify assessment and collection procedures. 
(c) Duplicate Written Filings Not Required.--Amends section 527(i)(1) to remove the requirement for duplicate written filings. 
(d) Application of Fraud Penalty.--Amends section 7207 regarding fraudulent returns. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow electronic filing and remove the requirement for duplicate written filings. Fraud penalties are updated to include specific sections for fraudulent returns. Reporting requirements are also updated to include electronic filing for organizations. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow electronic filing for organizations with contributions or expenditures exceeding $50,000. Additionally, the Secretary is required to make notices and reports available for public inspection on the Internet within 48 hours of filing. The Secretary is mandated to make the database of notices and reports searchable by various items, including names, states, contributors, and time periods. The contents of the notice under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are also amended to include additional details. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include additional details in the contents of the notice, such as whether the organization intends to claim an exemption from certain requirements. Timing of notice in case of material change is also addressed, with a requirement to give notice within 30 days of any material change in information. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include details on giving notice within 30 days of any material change in information. Effective dates for the amendments are specified for failures occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include notice requirements for material changes. Effective dates for the amendments are specified for different subsections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include notice requirements for material changes. A transition rule is established for material changes occurring within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, specifying when a notice must be filed. Notices, reports, or returns filed with the Secretary of the Treasury before the enactment of the amendments shall remain subject to disclosure provisions of section 6104 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
